content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle.
I've tried it for the reverse mode without reading the statement.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun and not trivial

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Tried in IDE and was fun and good quality.

Thanks to the feedback, I've modified the first test cases to make an exception clearer in reverse mode. These are presented to the player:

Input: 12, A# B C1 A B2 C A2 B C3 A B# C
Output: A# B C1 A# B2 C1 A2 B2 C3 A2 B# C3

Input: 13, A= B C1 A B2 C A2 B C3 A B= C B
Output: A B C1 A B2 C1 A2 B2 C3 A2 B C3 B

Input: 14, 1a 2b 3 1 2 3c 1= 2 3 1 2= 3a 1b 2
Output: 1a 2b 3 1a 2b 3c 1 2b 3c 1 2 3a 1b 2

Input: 15, G Db C# Gb C= D F# G F= C D G# F D= G
Output: G Db C# Gb C Db F# Gb F C Db G# F D G#

I've added a description for usual modes of play. In reverse mode, these are the test cases presented to the player:

Input: 1A 2B 3C 1 2 3 2 1A 3
Output: 1A 2B 3C 1A 2B 3C 2B 1A 3C

Input: A B C2 A B2 C A2 B C3 A B3 C
Output: A B C2 A B2 C2 A2 B2 C3 A2 B3 C3

Input: 1a 2# 3 1 2 3c 1= 2 3 1 2= 3a 1# 2 3
Output: 1a 2# 3 1a 2# 3c 1 2# 3c 1 2 3a 1# 2 3a

Input: G Db C# Gb C= D F# G F= C D G# F D= G
Output: G Db C# Gb C Db F# Gb F C Db G# F D G#
Using "=" is overcomplicated. The reverse mode is cool for the first 4 test cases. Test 5 ruins the fun... especially, it's not exposed in the example...

That's interesting, I felt that the puzzle was too easy without. The player will not see the validators, but in reverse mode they will see the other four test cases in lieu of the description, and not just the one example as it appears here. However, I could introduce = earlier.

I finally spoiled it for myself - I read the statement. I did come close to what was needed, but never close enough in my mind. I did follow what was going on with the letters and uppercase letters, and then when the other characters were added in the mix it seemed almost to do the same. *almost* -- I never made the final link that the '=' was a special other character, while '#' was not.

What might have helped me is if there is strictly only use of uppercase letters and digits as store character, and '=' for clear - but no '#'. Or, if the '#' similarly as the letters and digits is used both as key and store character - while only the '=' is never used as key.
Awesome, glad someone else tried that!
